<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 821, 94]]<|/det|>
Uranium-235 ( \(^{235}_{92}\mathrm {U})\) is a radioactive isotope of uranium that occurs naturally on Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 761, 123]]<|/det|>
Describe the composition and structure of a neutral atom of uranium-235.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 259, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 289, 146, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 514, 308]]<|/det|>
Another isotope of uranium is uranium-238.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 777, 339]]<|/det|>
Describe how an atom of uranium-238 differs from an atom of uranium-235.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 382, 920, 401]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 413, 144, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 920, 447]]<|/det|>
In the reactor in a nuclear power station, a nucleus of uranium-235 absorbs a slow-moving neutron and then undergoes nuclear fission.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
Two neutrons, a nucleus of xenon-140 ( \(^{140}_{54}\mathrm {Xe})\) and a nucleus of an element represented by E are produced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 507, 541, 526]]<|/det|>
Complete the equation for this fission reaction.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 546, 663, 575]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm {n}+\mathrm {}^{235}_{92}\mathrm {U}\rightarrow \mathrm {}^{140}_{54}\mathrm {Xe}+\mathrm {}^{...........}_{...........}\mathrm {E}+\mathrm {}^{2n}\]

Xenon-140 ( \(^{140}_{54}\mathrm {Xe})\) is radioactive. It decays by \(\beta\) -emission to isotope Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 647, 250, 664]]<|/det|>
